objects.name: UEFI
objects.description: TTPs related to UEFI

objects.name: System Enumeration
objects.description: Attackers aim to identify the target system's UEFI firmware version, vendor, and specific model. This information helps them understand the firmware's features, potential vulnerabilities, and available exploits.

objects.name: Boot Process Analysis
objects.description: Attackers study the UEFI firmware's boot process and associated components to discover potential weak points or misconfigurations. They look for vulnerabilities that could be leveraged to gain persistence, execute malicious code, or bypass security measures during the boot process.

objects.name: Component Manufacturers
objects.description: Attackers investigate the manufacturers of the various components integrated into the target system, including the motherboard, chipset, memory modules, storage devices, and network interfaces. They may assess the security practices, reputation, and potential vulnerabilities associated with these manufacturers.

objects.name: Firmware Analysis
objects.description: Attackers analyze the UEFI firmware to identify potential security weaknesses, such as outdated firmware versions, known vulnerabilities, or misconfigurations. They may also search for custom code or backdoors inserted by previous attackers.

objects.name: Firmware Development Process
objects.description: Attackers may attempt to gather information about the firmware development process, such as the tools, methodologies, and security practices employed by the firmware vendor or OEM. This information helps them identify potential weaknesses or entry points that can be exploited during the development or integration process.

objects.name: Firmware Source
objects.description: Attackers may attempt to identify the source of the UEFI firmware installed on a target system, such as the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) or firmware vendor. This information helps them understand the potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses associated with that specific firmware version or supplier.

objects.name: Hardware and Firmware Inventory
objects.description: Attackers gather information about the hardware components integrated into the system, such as the motherboard, chipset, storage devices, and network adapters. They also identify the firmware versions associated with these components, as outdated firmware can be a potential entry point for exploitation.

objects.name: Network Scanning
objects.description: Attackers perform network scanning to identify devices and services connected to the target system. This helps them understand the network topology, discover potential entry points, and identify systems that may have weak security configurations.

objects.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
objects.description: Attackers identify peripheral devices connected to the target system, such as USB devices, network adapters, or storage devices. This helps them understand the potential attack vectors associated with these devices and identify devices that may have weak security configurations.

objects.name: Social Engineering
objects.description: Attackers may engage in social engineering tactics, such as phishing emails, to gather additional information about the target system or potential users. This can include obtaining usernames, email addresses, or other details that can aid in later stages of the attack.

objects.name: Supply Chain Identification
objects.description: The process of identifying and exploiting vulnerabilities within the UEFI firmware and associated components that may have originated from the supply chain. The supply chain attack vector involves compromising the integrity of hardware, firmware, or software at various stages of the supply chain, from the manufacturing process to distribution and installation.

objects.name: Supply Chain Integrity
objects.description: Attackers may analyze the various stages of the supply chain to identify potential weak points that can be leveraged to compromise the integrity of the UEFI firmware. This includes assessing the security measures in place during manufacturing, transportation, storage, and installation of the firmware.

objects.name: System Architecture Mapping
objects.description: Attackers aim to identify the architecture and components of the target system, including the motherboard, chipset, processors, memory modules, storage devices, and network interfaces. This information helps them understand the system's capabilities, potential attack vectors, and areas of focus for exploitation.

objects.name: Third-Party Dependencies
objects.description: Attackers investigate the dependencies and third-party software or components used in the UEFI firmware. They may identify vulnerabilities or weaknesses in these dependencies that can be exploited to compromise the integrity or security of the UEFI firmware.

objects.name: Vulnerability Research
objects.description: Attackers search for publicly known vulnerabilities specific to the UEFI firmware, associated components, or the system software stack. They may also explore exploit databases, security advisories, or forums to uncover undisclosed vulnerabilities or zero-day exploits.

objects.name: Abusing Secure Boot
objects.description: Attackers abuse Secure Boot by exploiting vulnerabilities in the verification process or by injecting their own signed code to escalate privilege.

objects.name: Acquire Access
objects.description: The adversary gains access to the  target system using existing tools and techniques or via initial access broker tools that are available to be bought as a service

objects.name: Acquire Infrastructure
objects.description: Adversaries may establish infrastructure such as command-and-control (C2) servers to deliver payloads, receive instructions, or maintain persistence within targeted systems.

objects.name: Boot Configuration Analysis
objects.description: Attackers may explore the boot configuration settings in the UEFI firmware, such as the boot order, boot options, and boot manager entries. It involves studying the boot process and associated components to identify weak points or misconfigurations. This information can be useful for manipulating the boot process or altering boot parameters.

objects.name: Bootkit Installation
objects.description: Once the bootkit is executed, it establishes persistence by injecting itself into the boot process. This ensures that the malicious code is executed every time the system starts up, even if the UEFI firmware or bootloader is updated or replaced.

objects.name: Bypassing UEFI Password
objects.description: Some systems allow users to set passwords to protect UEFI settings. Attackers use multiple techniques to bypass or recover these passwords (such as dictionary/brute force attacks, keylogging, social engineering, etc), granting them administrative access and control over firmware settings.

objects.name: Capsule Update Hijacking
objects.description: The attacker intercepts the communication channel used to securely deliver UEFI capsule updates to the target system through various means, such as compromising the network infrastructure, tampering with the update distribution process, or compromising the update server and inject malicious code into the UEFI firmware environment.

objects.name: Certificate Management
objects.description: Attackers may develop capabilities that may include acquiring authentic digital certificates of the vendors or generating digital certificates to sign malicious UEFI code.

objects.name: Code Execution
objects.description: Code injections give attackers the ability to execute arbitrary code on a system by exploiting vulnerabilities in the UEFI firmware or associated components.

objects.name: Code Obfuscation
objects.description: The attackers obfuscate the malicious UEFI code to make it more difficult to analyze and identify its purpose. Obfuscation techniques can include encryption, encoding, or packing the code.

objects.name: Code Signing Certificate Abuse
objects.description: Code signing verifies the authenticity and integrity of software code by attaching a digital signature to it. With a stolen or fraudulent code signing certificate attackers sign malicious UEFI firmware, UEFI drivers, or other UEFI-related components that are executed during the boot process or firmware update, and will be considered legitimate due to their valid digital signatures.

objects.name: Compromise Accounts
objects.description: Attackers compromise accounts that have privileged access to compromise UEFI.

objects.name: Compromise Hardware
objects.description: Attackers may do malicious modifications on the chip, insert a trojan, or induce a vulnerability that can be exploited later once the hardware is employed to implement UEFI based system.

objects.name: Compromise Remote Update
objects.description: Attackers may attempt to exploit vulnerabilities in the firmware update mechanism provided by the UEFI firmware.  An attacker can trick the system into accepting and applying the malicious update, to deliver their payload into the UEFI firmware.

objects.name: Configuration Table Enumeration
objects.description: UEFI firmware uses configuration tables to store information about system hardware and resources. Attackers may enumerate these tables to gather details about the system's hardware components and configurations.

objects.name: Cover Channels
objects.description: Attackers use non-standard protocols and port to establish a hidden communication path

objects.name: Credential Storage in UEFI
objects.description: UEFI stores credentials, such as BitLocker recovery keys or TPM (Trusted Platform Module) certificates, within the firmware itself. Attackers may attempt to extract these credentials by compromising the UEFI.

objects.name: Data Obfuscation
objects.description: Attackers encrypt or encode the C2 commands or data payloads to evade detection by security monitoring systems. This can involve using custom encoding schemes, encryption algorithms, or obfuscation techniques to make the communication traffic appear benign or non-malicious.

objects.name: Develop Capabilities
objects.description: Attackers may develop capabilities such as exploits/bootkit/rootkit

objects.name: Digital Certificate and Key Extraction
objects.description: If digital certificates or encryption keys are stored in UEFI firmware for secure communication or firmware updates, attackers attempt to extract these credentials for later use.

objects.name: Direct Flashing
objects.description: Attackers attempt to replace the firmware with malicious versions to gain control of the system or introduce security vulnerabilities by writing the malicious firmware directly to the motherboard's UEFI chip or storage device, typically using specialized software or tools provided by the hardware manufacturer.

objects.name: Disable/Subvert Secure Boot
objects.description: The attackers disable or bypass Secure Boot, to skip integrity-check of firmware components and bootloader. This allows loading of unsigned or malicious code during boot, that enables establishing persistence.

objects.name: DLL Injection
objects.description: If UEFI firmware includes a built-in UEFI shell, attackers may attempt to inject malicious dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) into the shell, which can grant elevated privileges within the firmware environment.

objects.name: DMA Attacks
objects.description: The attackers exploit the Direct Memory Access DMA capabilities of peripheral devices such as Network Interface Card (NIC), Graphic Cards, and Storage Controllers to compromise the UEFI firmware or the underlying operating system. Attackers may carry out malicious code injection and privilege escalation.

objects.name: DNS Tunneling
objects.description: The attackers use DNS Tunneling to bypass network security measures by encapsulating non-DNS traffic (the data attackers wish to exfiltrate) within DNS queries and responses.

objects.name: Evasion Techniques
objects.description: Attackers may develop evasion techniques to avoid detection by security software and UEFI security features. This can involve obfuscating or hiding malicious code within the firmware.

objects.name: Evil Maid
objects.description: Attackers can gain unauthorized physical access to the target system to directly modify the UEFI firmware by accessing the SPI flash chip or other storage devices where the firmware is stored.

objects.name: Exploit Development
objects.description: Attackers may create or obtain exploit code to target specific UEFI vulnerabilities. This involves writing or customizing the UEFI driver to compromise the UEFI, potentially leading to persistent control over the system.

objects.name: Exploit Supply Chain
objects.description: Attackers may compromise the supply chain components of the UEFI systems to deliver the malicious payload to the target system

objects.name: Exploit UEFI Services
objects.description:
UEFI attackers may exploit various UEFI services to carry out the attack, such as EFI_BOOT_SERVICES to exploit various boot-related functions including the loading of bootloaders and operating systems, EFI_VARIABLE_SERVICES to modify UEFI variables, potentially altering system behavior or disabling security features, EFI_FILE_SERVICES to manipulate or replace critical UEFI firmware files, EFI_TEXT_INPUT_PROTOCOL to inject malicious commands
 or bypass security measures, and EFI_NETWORK_INTERFACE_IDENTIFIER_PROTOCOL to launch remote UEFI attacks, such as firmware updates over the network,

objects.name: Firmware Image Extraction
objects.description: Attackers attempt to extract the UEFI firmware image from the system for analysis or reverse engineering. This can provide insights into the firmware's internal structure and potential vulnerabilities.

objects.name: Firmware Update Hijacking
objects.description: Attackers hijack the firmware update process to inject malicious firmware containing code to extract credentials. This can be achieved if the firmware update process is not properly secured.

objects.name: Hardware Supply Chain
objects.description: Attackers can insert themselves into the hardware manufacturing process to compromise the hardware components such as the motherboard, chipset, OROM, etc.

objects.name: Hooking UEFI API/Service
objects.description: Attackers hook UEFI runtime services or redirect UEFI API calls to their own code. This allows them to intercept and manipulate system calls and evade security controls.

objects.name: Hooking UEFI Services
objects.description: UEFI runtime services provide various functions that are accessible even after the operating system has been booted, and attackers modify or "hook" the UEFI runtime services by injecting their malicious code or modifying the existing service handlers such as GetVariable and SetVariable ( to manipulate UEFI variables related to boot order, firmware settings, or security policies), LocateProtocol and LocateHandle ( to gain access to specific firmware interfaces or to locate target functions or resources), InstallProtocolInterface ( to introduce malicious code into  protocols or interfaces), AllocatePages and FreePages ( to allocate memory for their code or data structures, ensuring persistence), RaiseTPL (to gain higher privileges by raising Task Priority Level), etc.

objects.name: Insider Threat
objects.description: A disgruntled employee of the organization related to manufacturing/development/distribution/deployment of the UEFI can sell sensitive proprietary information to the UEFI attackers.

objects.name: Known Vulnerabilities
objects.description: Attackers identify known vulnerabilities in UEFI and associated components and exploit the unpatched vulnerabilities to gain access.

objects.name: Leaked Authentic Digital Certificates
objects.description: Leaked digital certificates, particularly those used for code signing or secure communication, can be exploited by attackers. If an attacker gains access to these certificates, they sign malicious firmware or bootloader components, making them appear legitimate during the Secure Boot verification process.

objects.name: Legitimate Services
objects.description: The attackers use legitimate services or protocols to proxy their communications, making it appear as normal traffic, and evading detection by blending in with legitimate network activities.

objects.name: Malicious Boot Loader Injection
objects.description: The attackers modify or replace the legitimate bootloader of the system with a malicious one. The bootloader loads the operating system (OS) into memory and allows the system to start up. Injecting a malicious bootloader can give attackers control over the boot process.

objects.name: Malicious Driver Injection
objects.description: UEFI can be attacked by injecting and executing a malicious driver during DXE phase of booting. This allows attackers to gain control over the system at a very early stage, potentially compromising UEFI security and integrity

objects.name: Malicious Payload Injection
objects.description: The attackers inject and execute malicious code or payloads within the UEFI firmware environment in the form of a custom code or firmware update giving control over the system's firmware and potentially compromising the system security and integrity.

objects.name: Malicious Remote Update
objects.description: The attacker exploits vulnerabilities in the UEFI's remote update process to inject malicious firmware updates by manipulating firmware update servers or using social engineering tactics to trick users into applying the update.

objects.name: Malware Creation
objects.description: Attackers may develop bootkits, or rootkits that are designed to evade detection and maintain control over the system.

objects.name: Manipulating UEFI Variables
objects.description: UEFI variables store system settings and configurations. Attackers may manipulate these variables to change security settings, boot order, or other critical configurations, thereby escalating their privileges within the firmware environment.

objects.name: Masquerading
objects.description: UEFI attackers use masquerading to camouflage their malicious activities and blend in with legitimate system processes to make their presence and actions appear legitimate, making it difficult for security tools to detect their malicious activities. This is achieved by employing various means such as spoofing digital signature, impersonating trusted entities (legitimate firmware/ hardware manufacturers), mimicking legitimate process names or by spoofing file and registry names associated with their malicious activities.

objects.name: Memory Scanning
objects.description: Attackers with the ability to scan the system's memory search for sensitive credentials that are temporarily stored in RAM during the boot process.

objects.name: Network Configuration and Credentials
objects.description: UEFI firmware store network-related configurations and credentials for services like PXE (Preboot Execution Environment) boot or remote management. Attackers may extract these credentials for unauthorized network access.

objects.name: Network Services Evasion
objects.description: UEFI attackers employ techniques to avoid detection while communicating over the network, such as using encrypted communication channels, steganography, or blending in with legitimate network traffic.

objects.name: Overflow Vulnerability
objects.description: Vulnerabilities occur when inputs to the UEFI system components are not properly validated or limit the amount of data that can be written to a buffer, causing data to overflow into adjacent memory regions.

objects.name: Payload Removal
objects.description: The attackers design their malware in such a way that it is capable of removing the malicious files after establishing persistence.

objects.name: Physical Access Exploitation
objects.description: Physical access to the UEFI system is abused to directly install the malware on the system or tamper with the UEFI image.

objects.name: Physical Memory Dump
objects.description: Attackers with access to the system's physical memory perform memory dumps to collect data stored in RAM. This data can include UEFI variables, SMM data, or other sensitive information temporarily present in memory during the boot process.

objects.name: Physical Supply Chain
objects.description: Attackers may compromise the physical storage and distribution component to deliver malicious payload to the UEFI firmware

objects.name: Platform Key Abuse
objects.description: The attackers compromise a legitimate platform key and sign malicious UEFI firmware, bootloaders, or drivers, making them appear legitimate and trusted by the UEFI. By signing their malicious code with stolen platform keys, attackers can bypass the secure boot process and gain persistence within the system,

objects.name: Secure Boot Bypass
objects.description: Secure Boot ensures only trusted and signed firmware, bootloaders, and drivers are allowed to execute during the boot process. Attackers discover and exploit vulnerabilities in the Secure Boot implementation that enable them to load and execute unsigned or malicious code, bypassing the integrity checks performed by Secure Boot.

objects.name: SMM Code Exploit
objects.description: If an attacker can compromise the highly privileged System Management Mode (SMM) code within UEFI firmware, they inject code to extract credentials stored in memory.

objects.name: SMM Code Injection
objects.description: SMM is typically used for power management, system hardware control, and system management tasks. Injecting malicious code into SMM by overwriting or modifying existing SMM code allows attackers to gain high control over the system and compromise its security.

objects.name: SMM Exploitation
objects.description: System Management Mode (SMM) is a highly privileged execution mode in UEFI firmware. Attackers exploit vulnerabilities in SMM code to gain control over the system at a low level, effectively escalating their privileges within the firmware.

objects.name: Software Supply chain
objects.description: Attackers may hijack the UEFI firmware development and distribution phase to compromise the firmware at its source/very early stage of creation.

objects.name: SPI Chip Access
objects.description: Attackers with physical access and technical expertise directly read the UEFI firmware chip to extract stored credentials.

objects.name: Staged Communication
objects.description: Attackers employ staged communication techniques where compromised systems initially connect to benign or legitimate websites or servers. These intermediaries act as proxies or stepping stones to establish connections with the actual C2 infrastructure, making it harder to trace the malicious traffic back to its source.

objects.name: Standard Internet Channel
objects.description: UEFI attackers establish network communication channels to connect to external command and control servers. They use these channels to send and receive instructions, exfiltrate data, and receive updates or additional payloads.

objects.name: Subvert Security Controls
objects.description: Attackers disable/subvert UEFI security mechanisms such as secure boot, disable/modify UEFI security policy, and change code signing policy to evade detection.

objects.name: System Information Enumeration
objects.description: Attackers collect information about the firmware version, UEFI drivers, and hardware components. This information can be useful for identifying potential vulnerabilities and attack vectors.

objects.name: UEFI Image Tampering
objects.description: Tampering with the firmware image is used to establish persistence, bypass UEFI security features, and create hidden backdoors within the firmware, providing unauthorized access to the system or compromising its security.

objects.name: UEFI Logs
objects.description: Attackers can retrieve measured boot logs (if enabled) or records related to UEFI updates to gather information about previous updates, vulnerabilities, or changes in the firmware.

objects.name: UEFI Runtime Service Exploitation
objects.description: The attackers target specific UEFI services related to UEFI variables, Protocols, Handles, and Task Level Priority (TLP) etc to achieve privilege escalation.

objects.name: UEFI Security Feature Bypass
objects.description: UEFI firmware includes various security mechanisms designed to protect the system against unauthorized access, malware, and other threats. The attackers discover and exploit the vulnerabilities to bypass or undermine the security features such as secure boot, capsule update, and code-signing certificate.

objects.name: UEFI Security Policy Alteration
objects.description: The attackers perform unauthorized modification or deletion of the UEFI security policies and settings related to Secure Boot, UEFI Secure Flash, platform key management, etc to escalate privilege, establish persistence, or create a backdoor.

objects.name: UEFI Settings Password
objects.description: UEFI implementations allow users to set passwords to protect access to UEFI settings. Attackers attempt to extract or bypass these passwords to gain unauthorized access to UEFI settings and credentials.

objects.name: UEFI Shell Commands
objects.description: Attackers use UEFI shell to access and extract sensitive credentials stored in UEFI variables or firmware components.

objects.name: UEFI Shell Exploitation
objects.description: If the UEFI implementation supports a shell environment, it can be exploited to execute arbitrary UEFI shell scripts or commands.

objects.name: UEFI Variable Enumeration
objects.description: Attackers enumerate UEFI variables to gather information about system settings, configurations, or stored data. Some UEFI variables may contain sensitive information, such as BitLocker recovery keys or Secure Boot settings.

objects.name: UEFI Variable Tampering
objects.description: UEFI variable tampering ensures that the attacker's malicious configurations or code remains effective across multiple system reboots. It involves changing the variables containing individual boot entries and defining the paths to bootloader files, the order in which boot devices are accessed during the boot process, PK and KEK variables, etc

objects.name: Vulnerability Exploitation
objects.description: The attackers exploit vulnerabilities in the UEFI firmware or associated components to gain unauthorized access, execute malicious code, or manipulate system behavior.

objects.name: Zero Day Vulnerability
objects.description: UEFI attackers may conduct thorough research to discover undisclosed vulnerabilities in UEFI firmware.

objects.name: Zero-day Vulnerability
objects.description: Attackers identify vulnerabilities that are yet to be discovered and patched by the UEFI vendors and exploit them to gain unauthorized access to the system.

objects.name: Collection
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to gather data of interest to their goal.

Collection consists of techniques adversaries may use to gather information and the sources information is collected from that are relevant to following through on the adversary's objectives. Frequently, the next goal after collecting data is to steal (exfiltrate) the data. Common target sources include various drive types, browsers, audio, video, and email. Common collection methods include capturing screenshots and keyboard input.

objects.name: Command and Control
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to communicate with compromised systems to control them.

Command and Control consists of techniques that adversaries may use to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network. Adversaries commonly attempt to mimic normal, expected traffic to avoid detection. There are many ways an adversary can establish command and control with various levels of stealth depending on the victim’s network structure and defenses.

objects.name: Credential Access
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to steal account names and passwords.

Credential Access consists of techniques for stealing credentials like account names and passwords. Techniques used to get credentials include keylogging or credential dumping. Using legitimate credentials can give adversaries access to systems, make them harder to detect, and provide the opportunity to create more accounts to help achieve their goals.

objects.name: Defense Evasion
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to avoid being detected.

Defense Evasion consists of techniques that adversaries use to avoid detection throughout their compromise. Techniques used for defense evasion include uninstalling/disabling security software or obfuscating/encrypting data and scripts. Adversaries also leverage and abuse trusted processes to hide and masquerade their malware. Other tactics’ techniques are cross-listed here when those techniques include the added benefit of subverting defenses.

objects.name: Discovery
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to figure out your environment.

Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.

objects.name: Execution
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to run malicious code.

Execution consists of techniques that result in adversary-controlled code running on a local or remote system. Techniques that run malicious code are often paired with techniques from all other tactics to achieve broader goals, like exploring a network or stealing data. For example, an adversary might use a remote access tool to run a PowerShell script that does Remote System Discovery.

objects.name: Exfiltration
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to steal data.

Exfiltration consists of techniques that adversaries may use to steal data from your network. Once they’ve collected data, adversaries often package it to avoid detection while removing it. This can include compression and encryption. Techniques for getting data out of a target network typically include transferring it over their command and control channel or an alternate channel and may also include putting size limits on the transmission.

objects.name: Impact
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to manipulate, interrupt, or destroy your systems and data.
 
Impact consists of techniques that adversaries use to disrupt availability or compromise integrity by manipulating business and operational processes. Techniques used for impact can include destroying or tampering with data. In some cases, business processes can look fine, but may have been altered to benefit the adversaries’ goals. These techniques might be used by adversaries to follow through on their end goal or to provide cover for a confidentiality breach.

objects.name: Initial Access
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to get into your network.

Initial Access consists of techniques that use various entry vectors to gain their initial foothold within a network. Techniques used to gain a foothold include targeted spearphishing and exploiting weaknesses on public-facing web servers. Footholds gained through initial access may allow for continued access, like valid accounts and use of external remote services, or may be limited-use due to changing passwords.

objects.name: Lateral Movement
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to move through your environment.

Lateral Movement consists of techniques that adversaries use to enter and control remote systems on a network. Following through on their primary objective often requires exploring the network to find their target and subsequently gaining access to it. Reaching their objective often involves pivoting through multiple systems and accounts to gain. Adversaries might install their own remote access tools to accomplish Lateral Movement or use legitimate credentials with native network and operating system tools, which may be stealthier.

objects.name: Persistence
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to maintain their foothold.

Persistence consists of techniques that adversaries use to keep access to systems across restarts, changed credentials, and other interruptions that could cut off their access. Techniques used for persistence include any access, action, or configuration changes that let them maintain their foothold on systems, such as replacing or hijacking legitimate code or adding startup code.

objects.name: Privilege Escalation
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to gain higher-level permissions.

Privilege Escalation consists of techniques that adversaries use to gain higher-level permissions on a system or network. Adversaries can often enter and explore a network with unprivileged access but require elevated permissions to follow through on their objectives. Common approaches are to take advantage of system weaknesses, misconfigurations, and vulnerabilities. Examples of elevated access include: 

* SYSTEM/root level
* local administrator
* user account with admin-like access 
* user accounts with access to specific system or perform specific function

These techniques often overlap with Persistence techniques, as OS features that let an adversary persist can execute in an elevated context.

objects.name: Reconnaissance
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to gather information they can use to plan future operations.

Reconnaissance consists of techniques that involve adversaries actively or passively gathering information that can be used to support targeting. Such information may include details of the victim organization, infrastructure, or staff/personnel. This information can be leveraged by the adversary to aid in other phases of the adversary lifecycle, such as using gathered information to plan and execute Initial Access, to scope and prioritize post-compromise objectives, or to drive and lead further Reconnaissance efforts.

objects.name: Resource Development
objects.description:
The adversary is trying to establish resources they can use to support operations.

Resource Development consists of techniques that involve adversaries creating, purchasing, or compromising/stealing resources that can be used to support targeting. Such resources include infrastructure, accounts, or capabilities. These resources can be leveraged by the adversary to aid in other phases of the adversary lifecycle, such as using purchased domains to support Command and Control, email accounts for phishing as a part of Initial Access, or stealing code signing certificates to help with Defense Evasion.

objects.name: Reconnaissance
objects.description: The process of gathering information and intelligence about potential cyber threats and adversaries. It involves collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data from various sources to gain insights into the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used by threat actors

objects.name: Resource Development
objects.description: The process of acquiring or creating various tools, techniques, knowledge, and infrastructure to facilitate and support malicious activities.

objects.name: Delivery
objects.description: The stage of a cyber attack where the attacker delivers or introduces malicious code or components into the UEFI firmware or the system's boot process.

objects.name: Exploitation
objects.description: The process of leveraging vulnerabilities or weaknesses in UEFI firmware, UEFI-based systems, or associated components to gain unauthorized access, execute malicious code, or perform other malicious activities.

objects.name: Persistence
objects.description: The ability of an attacker to maintain their presence or control over a compromised system across reboots or system restarts. It involves establishing a persistent foothold within the UEFI firmware or other system components to ensure that the attacker's malicious activities can continue even after a reboot. Persistence enables the attacker to maintain long-term access, execute code, and potentially evade detection.

objects.name: Defense Evasion
objects.description: Methods employed by malicious actors to avoid detection, circumvent security controls, maintain persistence, and evade security measures implemented by the target system's defenders within a compromised UEFI environment.

objects.name: Command and Control
objects.description: The infrastructure and communication channels that enable the attacker to remotely manage and control the compromised system or network. It involves establishing a covert communication channel between the attacker and the compromised UEFI firmware or associated components to issue commands, receive instructions, and exfiltrate data

objects.name: Discovery
objects.description: The process of gathering information about the target system, its UEFI firmware, hardware components, network environment, and potential vulnerabilities. It involves identifying and probing various elements to gain a comprehensive understanding of the target system's configuration, security posture, and potential attack surface.

objects.name: Privilege Escalation
objects.description: The process by which an attacker elevates their level of access or permissions within the compromised UEFI firmware or the associated system. Privilege escalation allows the attacker to gain higher privileges than initially obtained, enabling them to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or execute malicious code with elevated privileges.

objects.name: Credential Access
objects.description: The unauthorized acquisition or retrieval of sensitive credentials stored within the compromised UEFI firmware or associated system components. Credentials can include usernames, passwords, cryptographic keys, or other authentication tokens used to access various resources, such as operating systems, applications, databases, or network services.

objects.name: Collection
objects.description: The process of gathering specific information or data from the compromised UEFI firmware or associated system components. Attackers engage in collection activities to obtain valuable information that can aid them in further stages of their attack or to exfiltrate sensitive data for malicious purposes.

objects.name: Actions On Objective
objects.description: Specific actions or steps that UEFI attacker takes to achieve their objectives once they have gained access to a system or network are known as Actions on Objective. For UEFI attackers, the AOO may vary depending on the attacker's goals and the level of control they have over the UEFI firmware.

objects.name: UEFI
objects.description: ATT&CK framework as specific to UEFI

objects.name: Enterprise ATT&CK
objects.description: Below are the tactics and technique representing the MITRE ATT&CK Matrix for Enterprise. The Matrix contains information for the following platforms: Windows, macOS, Linux, AWS, GCP, Azure, Azure AD, Office 365, SaaS.

objects.name: Ben Gurion University
objects.description: Carrying out research in the field of UEFI
